statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Cardinal snap three-game skid
article.linkText: Stanford recovers from rocky start, sort of
article.story: DENVER (AP) -- After three straight losses, Stanford was looking for an easy night against a team from the smaller Sun Belt Conference. Denver, however, was not about to roll over. Rob Little had a key block in the closing seconds and Dan Grunfeld hit two free throws with 19 seconds left after grabbing an offensive rebound, helping Stanford hold off a challenge from Denver 56-52 on Monday night. Stanford (3-4) was coming off a 78-53 loss to Michigan State and was hoping to end a brutal, season-opening seven-game road trip with a win before heading to newly renovated Maples Pavilion on Saturday. Instead, the Cardinal allowed what should have been a lesser opponent to stay close until the final seconds. That wouldn't have happened last year, when Stanford finished 30-2 and reached the NCAA Tournament for the 10th year in a row. "We are the hunted right now," Little said. "Teams see us as 30-2 last year." Denver (4-3) saw a chance for an upset. Playing in front of a rare sellout crowd, the Pioneers held their own against the Pac-10 powerhouse, overcoming a shaky start to keep it close. Rodney Billups, younger brother of Detroit Pistons star Chauncey Billups, had 18 points and Andrew Carpenter added 13, but Denver just couldn't come up with the big plays down the stretch to pull off the upset. "We had a lot of chances to win the game," Billups said after playing in front of his brother for the first time in college. The Pioneers took a 50-49 lead with 2 minutes left on Billups' 3-pointer from the wing, then Stanford went back up on Chris Hernandez's two free throws. Billups had another chance after a Stanford turnover, but Little swooped in to block his layup attempt with about 25 seconds left. Nick Robinson then hit 1 of 2 free throws and Grunfeld sealed it with 19.2 seconds left after grabbing an offensive rebound on Robinson's miss. Grunfeld finished with 13 points and 10 rebounds, helping Stanford overcome a night when it shot 37 percent and was just 14-of-22 on free throws. "On offense we have to be patient," Stanford coach Trent Johnson said. "The people we face, it is pretty evident if we don't rebound and play defense, we are going to struggle. Our margin for error is pretty slim." Denver opened the season 4-2, beating the likes of North Dakota State, Eastern Washington, Cal State-Fullerton and South Dakota State. The Pioneers had a bit more trouble against the bigger, more athletic Cardinal early in this one. Muscling inside for easy shots and crowding the passing lanes to force turnovers at the other end, Stanford opened the game with a 10-3 run and later pushed the lead to 23-9. But after a dominating start, the Cardinal got sloppy to let Denver back in it. Stanford ended the first half without a field goal in the final 5:46, managing just two points on Grunfeld's free throws with 17 seconds left. The Cardinal shot just 38 percent in the half and had eight shots blocked -- five by Yemi Nicholson, who had seven total. Denver's defense spurred its offense, allowing the Pioneers to get out on the break and close the first half with a 15-4 run. Denver rebounded from an awful start to shoot 10-of-23 and trailed just 27-25 at halftime despite 10 turnovers. "We didn't get off to a good start. They were the attacker to start the game," Denver coach Terry Carroll said. "The last 10 or 11 minutes of the first half we played harder, got back into it." ^------= On the Net: University of Denver Pioneers: http://www.denverpioneers.com Stanford University Cardinal: http://gostanford.collegesports.com Sun Belt Conference: http://www.sunbeltsports.org
